On-line Chain Partitions of Up-growing Semi-orders

Stefan Felsner AG Diskrete Mathematik

Faculty of Mathematics and Computer Science Jagiellonian University
Lojasiewicza 6, 30-348 Kraków, Poland Grzegorz.Matecki@tcs.uj.edu.pl http://tcs.uj.edu.pl/Matecki Piotr.Micek@tcs.uj.edu.pl http://tcs.uj.edu.pl/Micek
Abstract.

On-line chain partition is a two-player game between Spoiler and Algorithm. Spoiler presents a partially ordered set, point by point. Algorithm assigns incoming points (immediately and irrevocably) to the chains which constitute a chain partition of the order. The value of the game for orders of width w𝑤w is a minimum number val⁡(w)val𝑤\operatorname{val}(w) such that Algorithm has a strategy using at most val⁡(w)val𝑤\operatorname{val}(w) chains on orders of width at most w𝑤w. We analyze the chain partition game for up-growing semi-orders. Surprisingly, the golden ratio comes into play and the value of the game is ⌊1+52​w⌋152𝑤\lfloor\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}\;w\rfloor.

Key words and phrases:
on-line, chain partition, order, dimension, semi-order

1. Introduction

On-line chain partitions of an order can be described as a two-person game between Algorithm and Spoiler. The game is played in rounds. Spoiler presents an on-line order, one point at a time. Algorithm responds by making an irrevocable assignment of the new point to one of the chains of the chain partition. The performance of Algorithm’s strategy is measured by comparing the number of chains used with the number of chains of an optimal chain partition. By Dilworth’s Theorem the size of an optimal chain partition equals the width of the order. The value of the game for orders of width w𝑤w, denoted by val⁡(w)val𝑤\operatorname{val}(w), is the least integer n𝑛n for which some Algorithm has a strategy using at most n𝑛n chains for every on-line order of width w𝑤w. Alternatively, it is the largest integer n𝑛n for which Spoiler has a strategy that forces any Algorithm to use n𝑛n chains on order of width w𝑤w.

The study of chain partition games goes back to the early 80’s when Kierstead [4] (upper bound) and Szemerédi (lower bound published in [5]) proved the estimates for on-line orders of width w𝑤w: (w+12)⩽val⁡(w)⩽5w−14binomial𝑤12val𝑤superscript5𝑤14\binom{w+1}{2}\leqslant\operatorname{val}(w)\leqslant\frac{5^{w}-1}{4}. It took almost 30 years until these bounds had been slightly improved. The story can be found in the survey [2].

The study of on-line chain partition on restricted classes of orders began in 1981 when Kierstead and Trotter [6] proved the following result: when Spoiler is restricted to presenting interval orders of width w𝑤w, the value of the game is 3​w−23𝑤23w-2. Among other classes of orders that have been studied thereafter are (𝐤+𝐤)𝐤𝐤(\mathbf{k+k})-free orders and semi-orders. Again we refer to [2] for details.

Up-growing on-line orders have been introduced by Felsner [3]. In this variant Spoiler’s power is restricted by the condition that the new element has to be a maximal element of the order presented so far. Felsner [3] showed that the value of the chain partition game on up-growing orders is (w+12)binomial𝑤12\binom{w+1}{2}. The case of up-growing interval orders was resolved by Baier, Bosek and Micek [1]. The value of the game in this variant is 2​w−12𝑤12w-1.

This paper resolves the on-line chain partition problem for up-growing semi-orders. An order 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is called a semi-order if it has a unit interval representation, i.e., there exists a mapping I𝐼I of points of the order into unit length intervals on a real line so that x<y𝑥𝑦x<y in 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} iff interval I​(x)𝐼𝑥I(x) is entirely to the left of I​(y)𝐼𝑦I(y). Alternatively semi-orders are characterized as the (𝟐+𝟐)22\mathbf{(2+2)} and (𝟑+𝟏)31\mathbf{(3+1)}-free orders (see Fig. 2).

Considering on-line chain partitions of semi-orders note that the general (not up-growing) case is easy to analyze: First, observe that the number of chains used by Algorithm can be bounded by 2​w−12𝑤12w-1. Let x𝑥x be the new point and consider the set Inc⁡(x)Inc𝑥\operatorname{Inc}(x) of points incomparable with x𝑥x. Clearly, the only chains forbidden for x𝑥x are those used in Inc⁡(x)Inc𝑥\operatorname{Inc}(x). Now width⁡(Inc⁡(x))⩽w−1widthInc𝑥𝑤1\operatorname{width}(\operatorname{Inc}(x))\leqslant w-1 since the width of the whole order does not exceed w𝑤w. Moreover, height⁡(Inc⁡(x))⩽2heightInc𝑥2\operatorname{height}(\operatorname{Inc}(x))\leqslant 2 as the presented order is (𝟑+𝟏)31\mathbf{(3+1)}-free. Therefore, |Inc⁡(x)|⩽2​(w−1)=2​w−2Inc𝑥2𝑤12𝑤2|\operatorname{Inc}(x)|\leqslant 2(w-1)=2w-2, proving that x𝑥x can be assigned to at least one of 2​w−12𝑤12w-1 legal chains.

It turns out that there is no better strategy for Algorithm. In other words, Spoiler may force Algorithm to use 2​w−12𝑤12w-1 chains on semi-orders of width w𝑤w. A strategy for Spoiler looks as follows:

  1. (1)

    Present two antichains A𝐴A and B𝐵B, both consisting of w𝑤w points in such a way that A<B𝐴𝐵A<B, i.e., all points from A𝐴A are below all points from B𝐵B. If Algorithm uses 2​w−12𝑤12w-1 or more chains, the construction is finished. Otherwise, suppose that k𝑘k chains (2⩽k⩽w2𝑘𝑤2\leqslant k\leqslant w) contain elements from A𝐴A and B𝐵B, namely let ai∈Aisubscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝐴𝑖a_{i}\in A_{i}, bi∈Bisubscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝐵𝑖b_{i}\in B_{i} for 1⩽i⩽k1𝑖𝑘1\leqslant i\leqslant k lie in the same chain.

  2. (2)

    Present k−1𝑘1k-1 points x1,…,xk−1subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑘1x_{1},\ldots,x_{k-1} in such a way that {a1,…,ai}⩽xi⩽{bi+1,…,bk}subscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖1…subscript𝑏𝑘\left\{a_{1},\ldots,a_{i}\right\}\leqslant x_{i}\leqslant\left\{b_{i+1},\ldots,b_{k}\right\} and xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} is incomparable to all the rest (the interval representation of the whole order looks as in Fig. 1). It is easy to verify that in such setting Algorithm is forced to use 2​w−12𝑤12w-1 chains.

The contribution of this paper is the following theorem.

Theorem 1.1.

The value of the on-line chain partition game for up-growing semi-orders of width w𝑤w is ⌊1+52⋅w⌋⋅152𝑤\lfloor\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}\cdot w\rfloor.

2. Up-growing Semi-orders

2.1. Outline

In this section we prove that the value of the on-line chain partition game for up-growing semi-orders equals ⌊φ⋅w⌋⋅𝜑𝑤\lfloor\varphi\cdot w\rfloor, where φ=1+52𝜑152\varphi=\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2} is the golden number. First, in Sect. 2.2 we collect some facts about semi-orders. Section 2.3 describes a strategy for Spoiler which forces Algorithm to use at least ⌊φ⋅w⌋⋅𝜑𝑤\lfloor\varphi\cdot w\rfloor chains on a semi-order of width w𝑤w. This sets the lower bound for the value of the game. In Sect. 2.4 we propose a strategy for Algorithm using at most ⌊φ⋅w⌋⋅𝜑𝑤\lfloor\varphi\cdot w\rfloor chains on semi-orders of width at most w𝑤w.

The presence of the golden number φ𝜑\varphi in the result of a chain partition game may seem surprising. In fact, it is the Fibonacci sequence (F0=0subscript𝐹00F_{0}=0, F1=1subscript𝐹11F_{1}=1 and Fi+2=Fi+Fi+1subscript𝐹𝑖2subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖1F_{i+2}=F_{i}+F_{i+1}) which appears in the counting argument of the upper bound and serves as a discrete counterpart of φ𝜑\varphi.

2.2. Basic Facts

For x,y∈𝐏𝑥𝑦𝐏x,y\in\mathbf{P} by x∥𝐏​yevaluated-at𝑥𝐏𝑦x\parallel_{\mathbf{P}}y we mean that x𝑥x and y𝑦y are incomparable in 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}. Let x↓𝐏={y∈P:y<x}x\oDownset_{\mathbf{P}}=\{y\in P:y<x\}, called a down set of x𝑥x in 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}, denote the set of predecessors of x𝑥x in 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}. Dually, let x↑𝐏={y∈P:y>x}x\oUpset_{\mathbf{P}}=\{y\in P:y>x\}, called an up set of x𝑥x, denote the set of successors of x𝑥x in 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}. If the order 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is unambiguous from the context we also write x↑x\oUpset instead of x↑𝐏x\oUpset_{\mathbf{P}} and x↓x\oDownset instead of x↓𝐏x\oDownset_{\mathbf{P}}. By X↓X\oDownset we mean ⋃x∈Xx↓\bigcup_{x\in X}x\oDownset.

The maximum and the minimum elements of a chain γ𝛾\gamma are denoted respectively by top⁡(γ)top𝛾\operatorname{top}(\gamma) and bottom⁡(γ)bottom𝛾\operatorname{bottom}(\gamma).

An order 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is called an interval order if it has an interval representation, i.e., there exists a mapping I𝐼I of points of the order into intervals on a real line so that x<y𝑥𝑦x<y in 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} iff max⁡I​(x)<min⁡I​(y)𝐼𝑥𝐼𝑦\max I(x)<\min I(y). Interval orders have several nice characterizations, see e.g. [7]. In our context the following two will be used repeatedly:

  1. (1)

    𝐏=(P,⩽)𝐏𝑃\mathbf{P}=(P,\leqslant) is an interval order iff the set of down sets (up sets) of elements of 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is linearly ordered with respect to inclusion, i.e., for p,q∈P𝑝𝑞𝑃p,q\in P either p↓⊆q↓p\oDownset\subseteq q\oDownset or p↓⊇q↓p\oDownset\supseteq q\oDownset. Note that this ordering of down sets corresponds to the order of left endpoints in an interval representation.

  2. (2)

    𝐏=(P,⩽)𝐏𝑃\mathbf{P}=(P,\leqslant) is an interval order iff 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is a (𝟐+𝟐)22\mathbf{(2+2)}-free order, i.e., 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} does not contain elements a,b,c,d∈P𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑑𝑃a,b,c,d\in P such that: a<b𝑎𝑏a<b, c<d𝑐𝑑c<d, a∥dconditional𝑎𝑑a\parallel d and c∥bconditional𝑐𝑏c\parallel b (see Fig. 2).

An interval order 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is called a semi-order if it has a unit interval representation, i.e., all intervals are of the same length. Semi-orders are also characterized in terms of forbidden structures: an interval order 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is a semi-order iff 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is a (𝟑+𝟏)31\mathbf{(3+1)}-free order, i.e., 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} does not contain elements e,f,g,h∈P𝑒𝑓𝑔ℎ𝑃e,f,g,h\in P such that e<f<g𝑒𝑓𝑔e<f<g and h∥e,f,gconditionalℎ𝑒𝑓𝑔h\parallel e,f,g (see Fig. 2).

2.3. The Lower Bound

Fix w𝑤w and consider the system (Iksubscript𝐼𝑘I_{k}) of k𝑘k linear inequalities

x0+x1+…+xj−1+2​xj−xj+1⩽w,j=0,…,k.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑗12subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗1𝑤𝑗0…𝑘x_{0}+x_{1}+\ldots+x_{j-1}+2x_{j}-x_{j+1}\leqslant w,\ j=0,\ldots,k. (Iksubscript𝐼𝑘I_{k})

From the following two propositions it immediately follows that there exists a strategy for Spoiler which forces Algorithm to use ⌊φ⋅w⌋⋅𝜑𝑤\lfloor\varphi\cdot w\rfloor chains on an up-growing semi-order of width w𝑤w. This is the lower bound needed for Theorem 1.1.

Proposition 2.1.

If (x0,x1,…,xk,xk+1)subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘1(x_{0},x_{1},\ldots,x_{k},x_{k+1}) is an integral solution of (Iksubscript𝐼𝑘I_{k}) with x0⩾x1⩾…⩾xk⩾xk+1=0subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘10x_{0}\geqslant x_{1}\geqslant\ldots\geqslant x_{k}\geqslant x_{k+1}=0 then there is a strategy for Spoiler to present an up-growing semi-order of width w𝑤w and force Algorithm to use at least w+x0𝑤subscript𝑥0w+x_{0} chains.

Proposition 2.2.

For each w𝑤w there is an integer k𝑘k and an integral solution of (Iksubscript𝐼𝑘I_{k}) with x0=⌊(φ−1)⋅w⌋⩾x1⩾…⩾xk>xk+1=0subscript𝑥0⋅𝜑1𝑤subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘10x_{0}=\lfloor(\varphi-1)\cdot w\rfloor\geqslant x_{1}\geqslant\ldots\geqslant x_{k}>x_{k+1}=0.

Proof of Proposition 2.1..

Fix w𝑤w, k>0𝑘0k>0 and an integer solution (x0,…,xk)subscript𝑥0…subscript𝑥𝑘(x_{0},\ldots,x_{k}) of (Iksubscript𝐼𝑘I_{k}) with x0⩾x1⩾…⩾xk⩾xk+1=0subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘10x_{0}\geqslant x_{1}\geqslant\ldots\geqslant x_{k}\geqslant x_{k+1}=0. The strategy for Spoiler induced by (x0,…,xk)subscript𝑥0…subscript𝑥𝑘(x_{0},\ldots,x_{k}) presents an up-growing semi-order 𝐏=(P,⩽)𝐏𝑃\mathbf{P}=(P,\leqslant) of width w𝑤w. The height of 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is at most 333. The points of 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} are presented in bundles so that the actual presentation sequence has the following structure

P=(A,C0,B1,C1,B2,C2,…,Ck,Bk+1).𝑃𝐴subscript𝐶0subscript𝐵1subscript𝐶1subscript𝐵2subscript𝐶2…subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘1P=(A,\,C_{0},\,B_{1},\,C_{1},\,B_{2},\,C_{2},\,\ldots,\,C_{k},\,B_{k+1}).

The set A𝐴A is exactly the set of minimal elements of 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}. Points of height 222 lie in C0∪⋃i=1k+1Bisubscript𝐶0superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘1subscript𝐵𝑖C_{0}\cup\bigcup_{i=1}^{k+1}B_{i} and all points from ⋃i=1kCisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝐶𝑖\bigcup_{i=1}^{k}C_{i} are of height 333.

Throughout the construction Spoiler maintains auxiliary sets D1,…,Dksubscript𝐷1…subscript𝐷𝑘D_{1},\ldots,D_{k}. Initially Di=∅subscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}=\emptyset for every i𝑖i. During the construction the following invariant will be kept:

Di⊆Bisubscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝐵𝑖D_{i}\subseteq B_{i} and Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} does not contain top of any chain used by Algorithm. (1)

Now, we describe the phases of the construction. The proof that the construction has all desired properties will follow thereafter.

Spoiler starts the construction by presenting an antichain A𝐴A of size w𝑤w. Algorithm has to use w𝑤w different chains.

Phase j​(0⩽j⩽k)𝑗0𝑗𝑘j\ (0\leqslant j\leqslant k).  In the j𝑗j-th phase Spoiler builds xj−xj+1subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗1x_{j}-x_{j+1} forcing paths. The points constituting these paths will go into the set Cjsubscript𝐶𝑗C_{j}.

The first point q0subscript𝑞0q_{0} of a forcing path dominates A∪⋃i⩽jBi𝐴subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝐵𝑖A\cup\bigcup_{i\leqslant j}B_{i}. Now, suppose that the first i+1𝑖1i+1 points of the path have been presented and let qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i} be the last of these points. If Algorithm assigned qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i} to a new chain or to a chain whose top is in A𝐴A, then qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i} is the last point of the forcing path. Otherwise, qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i} was assigned to some chain with a top b∈Bs𝑏subscript𝐵𝑠b\in B_{s}. In this case Spoiler updates Ds≔Ds∪{b}≔subscript𝐷𝑠subscript𝐷𝑠𝑏D_{s}\coloneqq D_{s}\cup\left\{b\right\} and then introduces qi+1>A∪B1∪…∪Bs−1∪Dssubscript𝑞𝑖1𝐴subscript𝐵1…subscript𝐵𝑠1subscript𝐷𝑠q_{i+1}>A\cup B_{1}\cup\ldots\cup B_{s-1}\cup D_{s}.

Note that the invariant (1) is kept, i.e., Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} does not contain any chain top. Algorithm has to assign qi+1subscript𝑞𝑖1q_{i+1} to a new chain or to a chain with top in A∪B1∪…∪Bs−1𝐴subscript𝐵1…subscript𝐵𝑠1A\cup B_{1}\cup\ldots\cup B_{s-1}. This means that if qi+1subscript𝑞𝑖1q_{i+1} is assigned to a chain with a top from Bs′subscript𝐵superscript𝑠′B_{s^{\prime}} then s′<ssuperscript𝑠′𝑠s^{\prime}<s. Thus, consecutive points q0,q1,…subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞1…q_{0},q_{1},\ldots of a forcing path (excluding the last one) are assigned to chains with tops from the Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}’s with decreasing indices. This proves that the path is finite.

The intuition is that with each forcing path Spoiler forces Algorithm to produce a skip chain, i.e., a chain of height 2 with its bottom in A𝐴A and its top in Cjsubscript𝐶𝑗C_{j} (avoiding all the Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}’s), or to use a brand new chain.

Assume that Spoiler constructed all the forcing paths and consider the set Aj⊆Asubscript𝐴𝑗𝐴A_{j}\subseteq A of bottom points of skip chains with tops in Cjsubscript𝐶𝑗C_{j}. Clearly, |Aj|⩽xj−xj+1subscript𝐴𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗1\left|A_{j}\right|\leqslant x_{j}-x_{j+1}. Now, Spoiler introduces a set Bj+1subscript𝐵𝑗1B_{j+1} consisting of xj−xj+1subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗1x_{j}-x_{j+1} points such that Aj∪Bj↓⊆Bj+1↓A_{j}\cup B_{j}\oDownset\subseteq B_{j+1}\oDownset and |Bj+1↓|=x0−xj+1\left|B_{j+1}\oDownset\right|=x_{0}-x_{j+1} (put B0=∅subscript𝐵0B_{0}=\emptyset). This means that if |Aj|<xj−xj+1subscript𝐴𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗1\left|A_{j}\right|<x_{j}-x_{j+1} or Aj∩Bj↓≠∅A_{j}\cap B_{j}\oDownset\neq\emptyset then Spoiler completes Bj+1↓B_{j+1}\oDownset with arbitrarily chosen points from A−(Aj∪Bj↓)A-(A_{j}\cup B_{j}\oDownset). This is possible as |Bj↓|+|Aj|⩽(x0−xj)+(xj−xj+1)=x0−xj+1⩽w=|A|\left|B_{j}\oDownset\right|+\left|A_{j}\right|\leqslant(x_{0}-x_{j})+(x_{j}-x_{j+1})=x_{0}-x_{j+1}\leqslant w=\left|A\right|, by (Iksubscript𝐼𝑘I_{k}).

To prove that the construction actually works and thus concludes the proof of Proposition 2.1 we have to verify the following three facts.

Fact 2.3.

𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is a semi-order.

Fact 2.4.

The width of 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is w𝑤w.

Fact 2.5.

Algorithm has to use at least w+x0𝑤subscript𝑥0w+x_{0} chains to cover 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}.

Proof of Fact 2.3.

We proceed in two steps, first we show that 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is an interval order and then that it is (𝟑+𝟏)31\mathbf{(3+1)}-free.

In order to prove that 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is an interval order we show that the down sets of points from 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} are linearly ordered with respect to inclusion. Indeed,

  1. (i)

    A↓=∅A\oDownset=\emptyset,

  2. (ii)

    B1↓⊆B2↓⊆…⊆Bk↓⊆AB_{1}\oDownset\subseteq B_{2}\oDownset\subseteq\ldots\subseteq B_{k}\oDownset\subseteq A,

  3. (iii)

    C0↓=AC_{0}\oDownset=A,

  4. (iv)

    if c∈Cj𝑐subscript𝐶𝑗c\in C_{j} is the starting point of a forcing path, then c↓=A∪(B1∪…∪Bj)c\oDownset=A\cup(B_{1}\cup\ldots\cup B_{j}),

  5. (v)

    if c∈Cj𝑐subscript𝐶𝑗c\in C_{j} is not a starting point, then there is an s𝑠s with c↓=A∪(B1∪…∪Bs−1∪Dst)c\oDownset=A\cup(B_{1}\cup\ldots\cup B_{s-1}\cup D^{t}_{s}).

The set Dstsubscriptsuperscript𝐷𝑡𝑠D^{t}_{s} from the last line refers to the respective set Dssubscript𝐷𝑠D_{s} at the moment when c𝑐c is introduced. Recalling that Dssubscript𝐷𝑠D_{s} can only grow over time and Ds⊆Bssubscript𝐷𝑠subscript𝐵𝑠D_{s}\subseteq B_{s} we can conclude that the down sets of elements of c𝑐c are linearly ordered with respect to inclusion. Hence 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is an interval order.

To see that 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is a semi-order suppose that 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} contains a (𝟑+𝟏)31\mathbf{(3+1)}-configuration d∥a,b,cconditional𝑑𝑎𝑏𝑐{d}\parallel{a,\,b,\,c} with a<b<c𝑎𝑏𝑐a<b<c. Since 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} has height at most 333 and A<⋃i=0kCi𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑘subscript𝐶𝑖A<\bigcup_{i=0}^{k}C_{i}, the only option is that a∈A𝑎𝐴a\in A, b,d∈⋃i=1k+1Bi𝑏𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘1subscript𝐵𝑖b,d\in\bigcup_{i=1}^{k+1}B_{i} and c∈⋃i=1kCi𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝐶𝑖c\in\bigcup_{i=1}^{k}C_{i} (C0subscript𝐶0C_{0} is excluded as it is incomparable to the Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}’s). Let i,j𝑖𝑗i,\,j be such that b∈Bi𝑏subscript𝐵𝑖b\in B_{i} and d∈Bj𝑑subscript𝐵𝑗d\in B_{j}. Then it is easy to see that a<d𝑎𝑑a<d if i⩽j𝑖𝑗i\leqslant j (as in this case a∈b↓⊆d↓a\in b\oDownset\subseteq d\oDownset) and d<c𝑑𝑐d<c otherwise (as c𝑐c being an element of a forcing path with c>b∈Bi𝑐𝑏subscript𝐵𝑖c>b\in B_{i} implies c>B1∪…∪Bi−1⊇Bj𝑐subscript𝐵1…subscript𝐵𝑖1superset-of-or-equalssubscript𝐵𝑗c>B_{1}\cup\ldots\cup B_{i-1}\supseteq B_{j}). This contradiction to d∥a,cconditional𝑑𝑎𝑐{d}\parallel{a,c} shows that 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is (𝟑+𝟏)31\mathbf{(3+1)}-free so it is a semi-order. ∎

Proof of Fact 2.5.

We will prove that Algorithm is forced to use at least w+x0𝑤subscript𝑥0w+x_{0} chains on 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}. First, we show that

all points in A−Bk+1↓A-B_{k+1}\oDownset are tops of the chains to which they are assigned.

Consider the set E𝐸E of end points of forcing paths presented in the game. Indeed, we have shown that chains in A−Bk+1↓A-B_{k+1}\oDownset are tops of the chains.   1. (i)

    |A−Bk+1↓|=w−x0\left|A-B_{k+1}\oDownset\right|=w-x_{0},

  2. (ii)

    |B1|+…+|Bk+1|=(x0−x1)+…+(xk−xk+1)=x0subscript𝐵1…subscript𝐵𝑘1subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘1subscript𝑥0\left|B_{1}\right|+\ldots+\left|B_{k+1}\right|=(x_{0}-x_{1})+\ldots+(x_{k}-x_{k+1})=x_{0},

Proof of Proposition 2.2..

We will show that for any w𝑤w there is a solution of (Iksubscript𝐼𝑘I_{k}) with x0=⌊(φ−1)⋅w⌋subscript𝑥0⋅𝜑1𝑤x_{0}=\lfloor(\varphi-1)\cdot w\rfloor. Consider the following sequence:

x0subscript𝑥0\displaystyle x_{0} =⌊(φ−1)⋅w⌋,absent⋅𝜑1𝑤\displaystyle=\lfloor(\varphi-1)\cdot w\rfloor,

Note that for any 0⩽a⩽x0𝑎𝑥0\leqslant a\leqslant x we have ⌊(φ−1)​(x−a)⌋⩽(φ−1)​x−(φ−1)​a<(φ−1)​x𝜑1𝑥𝑎𝜑1𝑥𝜑1𝑎𝜑1𝑥\lfloor(\varphi-1)(x-a)\rfloor\leqslant(\varphi-1)x-(\varphi-1)a<(\varphi-1)x and thus ⌊(φ−1)​(x−a)⌋⩽⌊(φ−1)​x⌋𝜑1𝑥𝑎𝜑1𝑥\lfloor(\varphi-1)(x-a)\rfloor\leqslant\lfloor(\varphi-1)x\rfloor. It implies that the sequence of xjsubscript𝑥𝑗x_{j}’s is decreasing. Moreover, it eventually gets to zero since the partial sum x0+…+xjsubscript𝑥0…subscript𝑥𝑗x_{0}+\ldots+x_{j} is getting larger. xj⩽(φ−1)​(w−x0−…−xj−1)=φφ+1​(w−x0−…−xj−1).subscript𝑥𝑗𝜑1𝑤subscript𝑥0…subscript𝑥𝑗1𝜑𝜑1𝑤subscript𝑥0…subscript𝑥𝑗1x_{j}\leqslant(\varphi-1)(w-x_{0}-\ldots-x_{j-1})=\tfrac{\varphi}{\varphi+1}(w-x_{0}-\ldots-x_{j-1}).

2.4. The Upper Bound

Consider a semi-order 𝐏=(P,⩽)𝐏𝑃\mathbf{P}=(P,\leqslant) with P=(a,b,c,d,e)𝑃𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑑𝑒P=(a,\,b,\,c,\,d,\,e) and the chain partition Γ:P∖{e}→ℕ:Γ→𝑃𝑒ℕ\Gamma:P\setminus\left\{e\right\}\rightarrow\mathbb{N} as shown in Fig. 3.

Point e𝑒e may be covered with a new chain (say, with number 444) or with one of the chains already used. In the latter case Algorithm may choose between 222 and 333. We say that chain α𝛼\alpha is valid for a new point x𝑥x extending an already partitioned order 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} if x𝑥x dominates all points from α𝛼\alpha in 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}. We claim that among the valid chains 222 and 333 defining Γ​(e)=3Γ𝑒3\Gamma(e)=3 is the better choice. Indeed, any future point p𝑝p presented by Spoiler and dominating c𝑐c will also dominate b𝑏b (otherwise, 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} would have a (𝟐+𝟐)22\mathbf{(2+2)} configuration which is forbidden in interval orders). On the other hand, Spoiler may play q𝑞q greater than b𝑏b but remaining incomparable to c𝑐c (see Fig. 4).

Hence, using the chain of c𝑐c for e𝑒e leaves more options for the future. Whenever the chains of two points x𝑥x and y𝑦y are valid and x↑⊊y↑x\oUpset\subsetneq y\oUpset then it seems safer to use the chain of x𝑥x. Our Algorithm ALG will go along this intuition.

Suppose that Spoiler introduces a semi-order 𝐏=(P,⩽)𝐏𝑃\mathbf{P}=(P,\leqslant) with a presentation order P=(p1,…,pn)𝑃subscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑛P=(p_{1},\ldots,p_{n}). We refer to the chains used by ALG as ALG-chains or just chains. With 𝐏xsubscript𝐏𝑥\mathbf{P}_{x} we denote the order consisting of all points presented prior to x𝑥x. We say that a chain α𝛼\alpha is valid for point x𝑥x if top⁡(α)top𝛼\operatorname{top}(\alpha) in 𝐏xsubscript𝐏𝑥\mathbf{P}_{x} is below x𝑥x in 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}. The options of ALG are to put x𝑥x into some valid chain or into a new chain. We are ready to describe Algorithm’s strategy. Let x𝑥x be a new point presented by Spoiler.

Algorithm ALG:If there is a valid chain for x𝑥x, then put x𝑥x into a valid chain α𝛼\alpha such that top(α)↑⊆top(β)↑\operatorname{top}(\alpha)\oUpset\subseteq\operatorname{top}(\beta)\oUpset in 𝐏xsubscript𝐏𝑥\mathbf{P}_{x} for all valid chains β𝛽\beta. Otherwise, if there is no valid chain, use a new chain for x𝑥x.

ALG is a greedy algorithm, i.e., it uses a new chain only when it is left with no other option. Note also that ALG has some freedom in choosing a chain for a new point x𝑥x as there may be many tops of valid chains for x𝑥x with the same minimum up set in 𝐏xsubscript𝐏𝑥\mathbf{P}_{x}.

The bound on the performance of ALG on width w𝑤w is stated in the following proposition. This is the upper bound part for Theorem 1.1.

Proposition 2.6.

ALG uses at most φ⋅w⋅𝜑𝑤\varphi\cdot w chains on any up-growing semi-order of width at most w𝑤w.

Suppose Spoiler presents a semi-order 𝐏=(P,⩽)𝐏𝑃\mathbf{P}=(P,\leqslant) with the presentation order P=(p1,…,pn)𝑃subscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑛P=(p_{1},\ldots,p_{n}) and width⁡(𝐏)⩽wwidth𝐏𝑤\operatorname{width}(\mathbf{P})\leqslant w. We may assume that ALG uses a new chain for the last point pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n}. If this were not the case Spoiler could stop the game earlier and the number of chains used by ALG would remain the same.

We partition 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} into layers. These layers will in some way reflect the preferences of ALG during the game. The point p∈𝐏𝑝𝐏p\in\mathbf{P} is significant if p𝑝p dominates at least one maximal point of 𝐏psubscript𝐏𝑝\mathbf{P}_{p}. By the linearity of down sets of an interval order 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} this is equivalent to the fact that p𝑝p has the largest down set at the moment of its presentation. Let e1,…,em−1subscript𝑒1…subscript𝑒𝑚1e_{1},\ldots,e_{m-1} be the significant points of 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}, sorted with respect to the presentation order (If 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} has no significant points then 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is an antichain and the thesis is trivial). These points define the partition of 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} into layers as follows (put e0↓=∅e_{0}\oDownset=\emptyset):

Disubscript𝐷𝑖\displaystyle D_{i} =ei↓−ei−1↓,for 1⩽i<m,\displaystyle=e_{i}\oDownset-e_{i-1}\oDownset,\quad\textnormal{for }1\leqslant i<m,
Dmsubscript𝐷𝑚\displaystyle D_{m} =P−em−1↓.\displaystyle=P-e_{m-1}\oDownset.

Thus, Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} (for 1⩽i<m1𝑖𝑚1\leqslant i<m) is exactly the set of maximal points of 𝐏eisubscript𝐏subscript𝑒𝑖\mathbf{P}_{e_{i}} covered by eisubscript𝑒𝑖e_{i}. Here is a list of helpful and easy properties of the Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}’s.

Fact 2.7.
  1. (i)

    d1↑⊋d2↑⊋…⊋dm↑d_{1}\oUpset\supsetneq d_{2}\oUpset\supsetneq\ldots\supsetneq d_{m}\oUpset, for all di∈Disubscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖d_{i}\in D_{i}.

  2. (ii)

    Dmsubscript𝐷𝑚D_{m} is exactly the set of maximal points of 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}. In particular, pn∈Dmsubscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝐷𝑚p_{n}\in D_{m}.

  3. (iii)

    Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} is an antichain, for every i𝑖i.

  4. (iv)

    If di∈Disubscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖d_{i}\in D_{i}, p∈P𝑝𝑃p\in P and di<psubscript𝑑𝑖𝑝d_{i}<p then D1∪…∪Di−1⊆p↓D_{1}\cup\ldots\cup D_{i-1}\subseteq p\oDownset.

  5. (v)

    If di∈Disubscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖d_{i}\in D_{i}, p∈P𝑝𝑃p\in P and di≮pnot-less-thansubscript𝑑𝑖𝑝d_{i}\nless p then p↓⊆D1∪…∪Dip\oDownset\subseteq D_{1}\cup\ldots\cup D_{i}.

  6. (vi)

    If di∈Disubscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖d_{i}\in D_{i}, p∈P𝑝𝑃p\in P and p𝑝p is presented prior to disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} then p↓⊆D1∪…∪Di−1p\oDownset\subseteq D_{1}\cup\ldots\cup D_{i-1}.

Proof.

(i) From ei∈di↑e_{i}\in d_{i}\oUpset but ei∉dj↑e_{i}\not\in d_{j}\oUpset for all j>i𝑗𝑖j>i and the linear order on the up-sets of elements we obtain di↑⊋dj↑d_{i}\oUpset\supsetneq d_{j}\oUpset.

(ii) The last significant point em−1subscript𝑒𝑚1e_{m-1} has the largest down set in 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}. This means that all points outside em−1↓e_{m-1}\oDownset, namely Dm=P−em−1↓D_{m}=P-e_{m-1}\oDownset, have empty up sets.

(iii) This follows from (ii) and the fact that Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} is the set of maximal points of 𝐏eisubscript𝐏subscript𝑒𝑖\mathbf{P}_{e_{i}}.

(iv) Suppose i>1𝑖1i>1 since for i=1𝑖1i=1 the claim is obvious. Clearly, di≮ei−1not-less-thansubscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑒𝑖1d_{i}\not<e_{i-1}. But if di>ei−1subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑒𝑖1d_{i}>e_{i-1} then ei−1↓⊊di↓e_{i-1}\oDownset\subsetneq d_{i}\oDownset. Therefore disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} is the next significant point after ei−1subscript𝑒𝑖1e_{i-1} or eisubscript𝑒𝑖e_{i} was presented before disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i}. Both cases are impossible as Di⊆ei↓D_{i}\subseteq e_{i}\oDownset, thus di∥ei−1conditionalsubscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑒𝑖1d_{i}\parallel e_{i-1}. Now, if di<psubscript𝑑𝑖𝑝d_{i}<p then by the linearity of down sets we obtain D1∪…∪Di−1=ei−1↓⊊p↓D_{1}\cup\ldots\cup D_{i-1}=e_{i-1}\oDownset\subsetneq p\oDownset.

(v) Suppose that p>d𝑝𝑑p>d for some d∈Dj𝑑subscript𝐷𝑗d\in D_{j}, j>i𝑗𝑖j>i. Then (iv) guarantees that Di⊆p↓D_{i}\subseteq p\oDownset. This implies di<psubscript𝑑𝑖𝑝d_{i}<p, contradicting the assumptions.

(vi) If i=m𝑖𝑚i=m then the thesis is trivial as Dmsubscript𝐷𝑚D_{m} is the set of maximal points of 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}. Thus, suppose i<m𝑖𝑚i<m. Recall that eisubscript𝑒𝑖e_{i} is the first presented point which dominates every point from Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}. Now as p𝑝p is presented prior to disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} and disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} precedes ejsubscript𝑒𝑗e_{j} for j⩾i𝑗𝑖j\geqslant i, we get that p𝑝p cannot dominate any point from Djsubscript𝐷𝑗D_{j}. ∎

With the next fact we prove that ALG always chooses a chain whose top is in the highest of the layers which contain tops of valid chains.

Fact 2.8.

Let di∈Disubscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖d_{i}\in D_{i}, dj∈Djsubscript𝑑𝑗subscript𝐷𝑗d_{j}\in D_{j}, i<j𝑖𝑗i<j and di,dj<xsubscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑑𝑗𝑥d_{i},d_{j}<x. If disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} is an ALG-top in 𝐏xsubscript𝐏𝑥\mathbf{P}_{x} and ALG uses its chain on x𝑥x then djsubscript𝑑𝑗d_{j} is not an ALG-top in 𝐏xsubscript𝐏𝑥\mathbf{P}_{x}.

Proof.

At the moment when Spoiler presents x𝑥x, both disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} and djsubscript𝑑𝑗d_{j} are already introduced (𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is up-growing). Since ej−1subscript𝑒𝑗1e_{j-1} was presented before djsubscript𝑑𝑗d_{j}, di∈ej−1↓d_{i}\in e_{j-1}\oDownset and dj≮ej−1not-less-thansubscript𝑑𝑗subscript𝑒𝑗1d_{j}\not<e_{j-1} we conclude that di↑⊋dj↑d_{i}\oUpset\supsetneq d_{j}\oUpset in 𝐏xsubscript𝐏𝑥\mathbf{P}_{x}. Hence if both disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} and djsubscript𝑑𝑗d_{j} are valid tops for x𝑥x then ALG has a preference for using the chain of djsubscript𝑑𝑗d_{j} for x𝑥x. ∎

Before we proceed with the proof we introduce the concept of a predecessor and a successor of a point with respect to some fixed chain partition. Let 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} be the chain partition of 𝐏=(P,⩽)𝐏𝑃\mathbf{P}=(P,\leqslant). For p∈P𝑝𝑃p\in P with p∈C𝑝𝐶p\in C for a chain C∈𝒞𝐶𝒞C\in\mathcal{C} we define:

  1. (i)

    The predecessor of p𝑝p in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is the point preceding p𝑝p in C𝐶C (if p𝑝p is the least point in C𝐶C then the predecessor of p𝑝p does not exist).

  2. (ii)

    The successor of p𝑝p in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is the point succeeding p𝑝p in C𝐶C (if p𝑝p is the largest point in C𝐶C then the successor of p𝑝p does not exist).

We fix an optimal chain partition 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O} of 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}. Since width⁡(𝐏)⩽wwidth𝐏𝑤\operatorname{width}(\mathbf{P})\leqslant w this partition consists of at most w𝑤w chains. With respect to this partition we denote the predecessor and the successor of p∈P𝑝𝑃p\in P by o−​(p)superscript𝑜𝑝o^{-}(p) and o+​(p)superscript𝑜𝑝o^{+}(p), respectively. Analogously, we refer to the predecessor and the successor of p𝑝p with respect to the the chain partition constructed by ALG as alg−⁡(p)superscriptalg𝑝\operatorname{alg}^{-}(p) and alg+⁡(p)superscriptalg𝑝\operatorname{alg}^{+}(p).

We arrive at the key concept of the proof: the alternating paths. Each such path starts at the bottom of an ALG-chain. We propose to understand it as a chain of events originating from the starting bottom. By counting the number of such paths we will get a bound on the number of chains used by ALG.

For each ALG-chain α𝛼\alpha define an alternating path q=(q0,…)𝑞subscript𝑞0…q=(q_{0},\ldots) as follows:

  1. (i)

    q0subscript𝑞0q_{0} is the bottom point of α𝛼\alpha,

  2. (ii)

    q2​i+1=o−​(q2​i)subscript𝑞2𝑖1superscript𝑜subscript𝑞2𝑖q_{2i+1}=o^{-}(q_{2i}), if o−​(q2​i)superscript𝑜subscript𝑞2𝑖o^{-}(q_{2i}) does exist,

  3. (iii)

    q2​i+2=alg+⁡(q2​i+1)subscript𝑞2𝑖2superscriptalgsubscript𝑞2𝑖1q_{2i+2}=\operatorname{alg}^{+}(q_{2i+1}), if alg+⁡(q2​i+1)superscriptalgsubscript𝑞2𝑖1\operatorname{alg}^{+}(q_{2i+1}) does exist.

We claim that for each path q𝑞q all the q2​isubscript𝑞2𝑖q_{2i}’s are pairwise distinct and so are all the q2​i+1subscript𝑞2𝑖1q_{2i+1}’s. Indeed, note that q0≠q2​isubscript𝑞0subscript𝑞2𝑖q_{0}\neq q_{2i} for i>0𝑖0i>0 as q2​i=alg+⁡(q2​i−1)subscript𝑞2𝑖superscriptalgsubscript𝑞2𝑖1q_{2i}=\operatorname{alg}^{+}(q_{2i-1}) is not a bottom of an ALG-chain, while q0subscript𝑞0q_{0} is defined as a bottom. Now suppose that the claim does not hold and consider the least i𝑖i such that qi=qjsubscript𝑞𝑖subscript𝑞𝑗q_{i}=q_{j} for some j>i𝑗𝑖j>i where i𝑖i and j𝑗j have the same parity. If i𝑖i and j𝑗j are even we get qi−1=alg−⁡(qi)=alg−⁡(qj)=qj−1subscript𝑞𝑖1superscriptalgsubscript𝑞𝑖superscriptalgsubscript𝑞𝑗subscript𝑞𝑗1q_{i-1}=\operatorname{alg}^{-}(q_{i})=\operatorname{alg}^{-}(q_{j})=q_{j-1} and if they are odd we get qi−1=o+​(qi)=o+​(qj)=qj−1subscript𝑞𝑖1superscript𝑜subscript𝑞𝑖superscript𝑜subscript𝑞𝑗subscript𝑞𝑗1q_{i-1}=o^{+}(q_{i})=o^{+}(q_{j})=q_{j-1}. In both cases this contradicts the choice of i𝑖i. This fact implies that the alternating paths are finite. Note that an alternating path q=(q0,…,ql)𝑞subscript𝑞0…subscript𝑞𝑙q=(q_{0},\ldots,q_{l}) is uniquely determined by any qi∈qsubscript𝑞𝑖𝑞q_{i}\in q together with the information whether qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i} is an odd or a even element. Altogether we have proven the following fact:

Fact 2.9.

For an alternating path q=(q0,…,ql)𝑞subscript𝑞0…subscript𝑞𝑙q=(q_{0},\ldots,q_{l}) all the qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i}’s with the same parity of indices are pairwise distinct, i.e. q2​i≠q2​jsubscript𝑞2𝑖subscript𝑞2𝑗q_{2i}\neq q_{2j} and q2​i+1≠q2​j+1subscript𝑞2𝑖1subscript𝑞2𝑗1q_{2i+1}\neq q_{2j+1} for i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j. Moreover, each p∈P𝑝𝑃p\in P occurs in at most two alternating paths: once with an odd index and once with an even index.

For an alternating path q=(q0,…,ql)𝑞subscript𝑞0…subscript𝑞𝑙q=(q_{0},\ldots,q_{l}) we call the q2​isubscript𝑞2𝑖q_{2i}’s the up-points of q𝑞q and the q2​i+1subscript𝑞2𝑖1q_{2i+1}’s the down-points of q𝑞q. An alternating path q=(q0,…,ql)𝑞subscript𝑞0…subscript𝑞𝑙q=(q_{0},\ldots,q_{l}) is an up-path if its last point is an up-point, otherwise, q𝑞q is a down-path. Note that an up-path connects the bottom of an ALG-chain with the bottom of an 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O}-chain, hence, there are at most w𝑤w up-paths (see Fact 2.12). The goal is to bound the number of down-paths.

From our perspective the important layers in the partition of P=D1∪…∪Dm𝑃subscript𝐷1…subscript𝐷𝑚P=D_{1}\cup\ldots\cup D_{m} will be those containing at least one end point of a down-path. Define

I={i:there is a down-path ending in Di}={i0<i1<…<is}.𝐼conditional-set𝑖there is a down-path ending in Disubscript𝑖0subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑖𝑠I=\left\{\;i:\ \textnormal{there is a down-path ending in $D_{i}$}\;\right\}=\left\{\;i_{0}<i_{1}<\ldots<i_{s}\;\right\}.

Note that m∉I𝑚𝐼m\not\in I being an end point of a down-path has a non-empty up set, while up sets of all points in Dmsubscript𝐷𝑚D_{m} are empty (see Fact 2.7.(ii)). This means

is<m.subscript𝑖𝑠𝑚i_{s}<m. (2)

From the definition of I𝐼I we immediately obtain:

Fact 2.10.

There is an ALG-top in every Dijsubscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑗D_{i_{j}}, for 0⩽j⩽s0𝑗𝑠0\leqslant j\leqslant s.

The next fact basically states that Di0∪…∪Dmsubscript𝐷subscript𝑖0…subscript𝐷𝑚D_{i_{0}}\cup\ldots\cup D_{m} induce an order of height at most 333.

Fact 2.11.

Di0+1∪…∪Dm−1subscript𝐷subscript𝑖01…subscript𝐷𝑚1D_{i_{0}+1}\cup\ldots\cup D_{m-1} is an antichain.

Proof.

In order to get contradiction suppose that there are d,d′∈Di0+1∪…∪Dm−1𝑑superscript𝑑′subscript𝐷subscript𝑖01…subscript𝐷𝑚1d,\,d^{\prime}\in D_{i_{0}+1}\cup\ldots\cup D_{m-1} and that d<d′𝑑superscript𝑑′d<d^{\prime}. As d′superscript𝑑′d^{\prime} dominates a point from a layer higher than Di0subscript𝐷subscript𝑖0D_{i_{0}}, we get from Fact 2.7(iv) that Di0⊆d′↓D_{i_{0}}\subseteq d^{\prime}\oDownset. On the other hand, since d′∉Dmsuperscript𝑑′subscript𝐷𝑚d^{\prime}\not\in D_{m} there must be some point d′′>d′superscript𝑑′′superscript𝑑′d^{\prime\prime}>d^{\prime} (see Fact 2.7(ii)). Fix some t∈Di0𝑡subscript𝐷subscript𝑖0t\in D_{i_{0}} that remains an ALG-top throughout the game (such t𝑡t exists by Fact 2.10). Recall that pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n}, the last point presented by Spoiler, is incomparable with t𝑡t as otherwise pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} would not be assigned to a new ALG-chain. Together this shows that pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} and t<d′<d′′𝑡superscript𝑑′superscript𝑑′′t<d^{\prime}<d^{\prime\prime} form a (𝟑+𝟏)31\mathbf{(3+1)}-configuration. This is impossible since 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is a semi-order. ∎

We now introduce variables that count the number of paths with respect to their end points. Define

   xUsubscript𝑥𝑈x_{U} the total number of up-paths,
   xjsubscript𝑥𝑗x_{j} the number of down-paths ending in ⋃i⩾ijDisubscript𝑖subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝐷𝑖\bigcup_{i\geqslant i_{j}}D_{i}, for j=0,…,s𝑗0…𝑠j=0,\ldots,s,
   xs+1subscript𝑥𝑠1x_{s+1} =0absent0=0.

In terms of these variables the number of chains used by ALG can be expressed as

xU+x0.subscript𝑥𝑈subscript𝑥0x_{U}+x_{0}.
Fact 2.12.

xU⩽wsubscript𝑥𝑈𝑤x_{U}\leqslant w.

Proof.

Consider the set U𝑈U of end points of up-paths. By Fact 2.9 these end points are pairwise distinct and |U|=xU𝑈subscript𝑥𝑈\left|U\right|=x_{U}. As each point in U𝑈U is a bottom point of its chain in 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O} these points belong to different chains in 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O}. Therefore, xU=|U|⩽|𝒪|⩽wsubscript𝑥𝑈𝑈𝒪𝑤x_{U}=\left|U\right|\leqslant\left|\mathcal{O}\right|\leqslant w. ∎

Throughout the rest of the paper our efforts are targeted on bounding the number x0subscript𝑥0x_{0} of down-paths. In the following two lemmas we will present a system of inequalities involving x0subscript𝑥0x_{0} and the other xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}’s. From these inequalities we will derive the desired constraints on the value of x0subscript𝑥0x_{0}.

Lemma 2.13.

x0+x0−x1⩽wsubscript𝑥0subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1𝑤x_{0}+x_{0}-x_{1}\leqslant w.

Lemma 2.14.

x0+x1+…+xj+(xj−xj+1)⩽wsubscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗1𝑤x_{0}+x_{1}+\ldots+x_{j}+(x_{j}-x_{j+1})\leqslant w, for j=1,…,s𝑗1…𝑠j=1,\ldots,s.

We need some preparations for the proofs of the lemmas. In the counting arguments on which the proofs are based we will be often showing that certain sets are disjoint. Below we introduce a criterion that will help us do the bookkeeping.

Point p∈P𝑝𝑃p\in P is a good point if o−​(p)superscript𝑜𝑝o^{-}(p) exists and o−​(p)superscript𝑜𝑝o^{-}(p) is an ALG-top at the moment when p𝑝p is presented, i.e., o−​(p)superscript𝑜𝑝o^{-}(p) is a top of its ALG-chain in 𝐏psubscript𝐏𝑝\mathbf{P}_{p}. Simple enough, point p𝑝p is considered bad if it is not good.

Fact 2.15 states that the penultimate point of a down-path is always good. Fact 2.16 says that if a down-path ends in Dijsubscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑗D_{i_{j}} then it contains j+1𝑗1j+1 bad up-points. Fact 2.17 is a technical statement used in the proof of Lemma 2.14.

Fact 2.15.

The penultimate point of a down-path is a good point and lies in Dmsubscript𝐷𝑚D_{m}.

Proof.

Let q=(q0,…,ql−1,ql)𝑞subscript𝑞0…subscript𝑞𝑙1subscript𝑞𝑙q=(q_{0},\ldots,q_{l-1},q_{l}) be a down-path. We have ql=o−​(ql−1)subscript𝑞𝑙superscript𝑜subscript𝑞𝑙1q_{l}=o^{-}(q_{l-1}) and since q𝑞q ends with ql=o−​(ql−1)subscript𝑞𝑙superscript𝑜subscript𝑞𝑙1q_{l}=o^{-}(q_{l-1}) this point must be an ALG-top in 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}. This shows that ql−1subscript𝑞𝑙1q_{l-1} is good.

To prove that ql−1∈Dmsubscript𝑞𝑙1subscript𝐷𝑚q_{l-1}\in D_{m} we are going to prove an equivalent condition that the up set of ql−1subscript𝑞𝑙1q_{l-1} is empty (see Fact 2.7(ii)). Recall that the last point presented in 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P}, namely pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n}, receives a new ALG-chain. This means that there is no valid chain for pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} and in particular, pn≯qlnot-greater-thansubscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑞𝑙p_{n}\ngtr q_{l}. From pn↑=∅p_{n}\oUpset=\emptyset we get pn∥qlconditionalsubscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑞𝑙p_{n}\parallel q_{l}. Now, if there was a point x>ql−1𝑥subscript𝑞𝑙1x>q_{l-1} then pn,ql,ql−1,xsubscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑞𝑙subscript𝑞𝑙1𝑥p_{n},q_{l},q_{l-1},x would form a (𝟑+𝟏)31\mathbf{(3+1)}-configuration. This is impossible since 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} is a semi-order. ∎

Fact 2.16.

A down-path q𝑞q ending in Dijsubscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑗D_{i_{j}} contains j+1𝑗1j+1 bad up-points {y0,…,yj}subscript𝑦0…subscript𝑦𝑗\left\{y_{0},\ldots,y_{j}\right\} such that o−​(yk)∈Diksuperscript𝑜subscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑘o^{-}(y_{k})\in D_{i_{k}}, for 0⩽k⩽j0𝑘𝑗0\leqslant k\leqslant j.

Proof.

Fix k𝑘k and define yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k} to be the first up-point in q𝑞q such that o−​(yk)∈Dlsuperscript𝑜subscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝐷𝑙o^{-}(y_{k})\in D_{l} for some l⩾ik𝑙subscript𝑖𝑘l\geqslant i_{k}. Such point does exist, as the penultimate point in q𝑞q is a candidate for yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k}.

Claim. yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k} is a bad point.

Suppose yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k} is the first point of q𝑞q. In this case ALG uses a new chain on yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k}. Since ALG is greedy there is no valid chain for yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k} at the moment it is presented. In particular, o−​(yk)superscript𝑜subscript𝑦𝑘o^{-}(y_{k}) is not an ALG-top in 𝐏yksubscript𝐏subscript𝑦𝑘\mathbf{P}_{y_{k}} and therefore yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k} is a bad point.

If yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k} is not the first point of q=(…,p,o−​(p),yk,o−​(yk),…)𝑞…𝑝superscript𝑜𝑝subscript𝑦𝑘superscript𝑜subscript𝑦𝑘…q=(\ldots,p,o^{-}(p),y_{k},o^{-}(y_{k}),\ldots), then we know that p𝑝p did not qualify for yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k} and therefore alg−⁡(yk)=o−​(p)∈D1∪…∪Dik−1superscriptalgsubscript𝑦𝑘superscript𝑜𝑝subscript𝐷1…subscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑘1\operatorname{alg}^{-}(y_{k})=o^{-}(p)\in D_{1}\cup\ldots\cup D_{i_{k}-1}. From Fact 2.8 it follows that o−​(yk)superscript𝑜subscript𝑦𝑘o^{-}(y_{k}) is not an ALG-top in 𝐏iksubscript𝐏subscript𝑖𝑘\mathbf{P}_{i_{k}} and again yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k} is bad. This proves the claim.

It remains to show that o−​(yk)∈Diksuperscript𝑜subscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑘o^{-}(y_{k})\in D_{i_{k}}. Fix an ALG-top t∈Dik𝑡subscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑘t\in D_{i_{k}} (Fact 2.10). Note that t≮yknot-less-than𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘t\nless y_{k} as otherwise ALG would have given preference to the chain of t𝑡t instead of the one it used for yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k}. From Fact 2.7(v) we get yk↓⊆D1∪…∪Diky_{k}\oDownset\subseteq D_{1}\cup\ldots\cup D_{i_{k}}. From this and the definition of yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k} we conclude o−​(yk)∈Diksuperscript𝑜subscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑘o^{-}(y_{k})\in D_{i_{k}}. ∎

Fact 2.17.

For every j𝑗j (0⩽j⩽s)0𝑗𝑠(0\leqslant j\leqslant s) and down-path q𝑞q there is an up-point u∈q𝑢𝑞u\in q such that one of the following two conditions is true:

  1. (i)

    u∈Dij+1∪…∪Dm𝑢subscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑗1…subscript𝐷𝑚u\in D_{i_{j}+1}\cup\ldots\cup D_{m} and o−​(u)∈Di0superscript𝑜𝑢subscript𝐷subscript𝑖0o^{-}(u)\in D_{i_{0}}, or

  2. (ii)

    u𝑢u is good and o−​(u)∈Di0+1∪…∪Dij−1superscript𝑜𝑢subscript𝐷subscript𝑖01…subscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑗1o^{-}(u)\in D_{i_{0}+1}\cup\ldots\cup D_{i_{j}-1}.

Proof.

Fix j𝑗j and a down-path q𝑞q. Let a𝑎a be the last up-point in q𝑞q such that o−​(a)∈Dksuperscript𝑜𝑎subscript𝐷𝑘o^{-}(a)\in D_{k} for some k⩽i0𝑘subscript𝑖0k\leqslant i_{0}. First we are going to prove that o−​(a)∈Di0superscript𝑜𝑎subscript𝐷subscript𝑖0o^{-}(a)\in D_{i_{0}}. It is trivial if o−​(a)superscript𝑜𝑎o^{-}(a) is the last point of q𝑞q as the first layer with an end of a down-path is Di0subscript𝐷subscript𝑖0D_{i_{0}}. If o−​(a)superscript𝑜𝑎o^{-}(a) is not the last point then let b𝑏b be the next point of q𝑞q, i.e. q=(…,a,o−​(a),b,o−​(b),…)𝑞…𝑎superscript𝑜𝑎𝑏superscript𝑜𝑏…q=(\ldots,a,o^{-}(a),b,o^{-}(b),\ldots). From the way point a𝑎a is chosen we have o−​(b)∈Dlsuperscript𝑜𝑏subscript𝐷𝑙o^{-}(b)\in D_{l}, for some l>i0𝑙subscript𝑖0l>i_{0}. By Fact 2.7(iv) b>o−​(b)∈Dl𝑏superscript𝑜𝑏subscript𝐷𝑙b>o^{-}(b)\in D_{l} implies Di0⊆b↓D_{i_{0}}\subseteq b\oDownset. Now, recall that there is an ALG-top t∈Di0𝑡subscript𝐷subscript𝑖0t\in D_{i_{0}} (Fact 2.10). In particular, at the moment when b𝑏b was introduced the chain of t∈Di0𝑡subscript𝐷subscript𝑖0t\in D_{i_{0}} was valid for b𝑏b. Since ALG has chosen alg−⁡(b)=o−​(a)∈Dksuperscriptalg𝑏superscript𝑜𝑎subscript𝐷𝑘\operatorname{alg}^{-}(b)=o^{-}(a)\in D_{k} we get k⩾i0𝑘subscript𝑖0k\geqslant i_{0} (Fact 2.8). Since a𝑎a was chosen such that o−​(a)∈Dksuperscript𝑜𝑎subscript𝐷𝑘o^{-}(a)\in D_{k} for some k⩽i0𝑘subscript𝑖0k\leqslant i_{0} we get k=i0𝑘subscript𝑖0k=i_{0}.

If a∈Dij+1∪…∪Dm𝑎subscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑗1…subscript𝐷𝑚a\in D_{i_{j}+1}\cup\ldots\cup D_{m} then a𝑎a fulfills the condition for the u𝑢u of (i) and we are done. We therefore know that

a∈Di0+1∪…∪Dij.𝑎subscript𝐷subscript𝑖01…subscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑗a\in D_{i_{0}+1}\cup\ldots\cup D_{i_{j}}. (3)

Since ij<msubscript𝑖𝑗𝑚i_{j}<m (see (2)) we have a∉Dm𝑎subscript𝐷𝑚a\not\in D_{m}, hence, there is a point a′∈Psuperscript𝑎′𝑃a^{\prime}\in P with a′>asuperscript𝑎′𝑎a^{\prime}>a. Note that o−​(a)superscript𝑜𝑎o^{-}(a) can’t be the last point of q𝑞q. Otherwise, a𝑎a would be the penultimate point of q𝑞q which is in Dmsubscript𝐷𝑚D_{m} (Fact 2.15). Let c𝑐c be the last up-point in q𝑞q presented by Spoiler prior to a𝑎a (i.e. in 𝐏asubscript𝐏𝑎\mathbf{P}_{a}). There is such a point as b𝑏b is an up-point of q𝑞q and it is presented prior to a𝑎a. Since b𝑏b comes after a𝑎a on q𝑞q this also holds for c𝑐c, i.e.,

It remains to prove that o−​(c)∈Di0+1∪…∪Dij−1superscript𝑜𝑐subscript𝐷subscript𝑖01…subscript𝐷subscript𝑖𝑗1o^{-}(c)\in D_{i_{0}+1}\cup\ldots\cup D_{i_{j}-1}. With these preparations we are ready for the proofs of Lemmas 2.13 and 2.14.

Proof of Lemma 2.13..

We are going to construct an antichain in 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} of size x0+x0−x1subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1x_{0}+x_{0}-x_{1}. This implies the statement.

By Fact 2.16 a down-path q𝑞q contains a bad up-point yqsubscript𝑦𝑞y_{q} with o−​(yq)∈Di0superscript𝑜subscript𝑦𝑞subscript𝐷subscript𝑖0o^{-}(y_{q})\in D_{i_{0}}. Since x0subscript𝑥0x_{0} is just the number of down-paths and Y𝑌Y contains a point from each down-path we get |Y|=x0𝑌subscript𝑥0\left|Y\right|=x_{0}. Let Z𝑍Z be the set of penultimate points of down-paths ending in Di0subscript𝐷subscript𝑖0D_{i_{0}}. The number of such paths is x0−x1subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1x_{0}-x_{1}. hence |Z|=x0−x1𝑍subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1\left|Z\right|=x_{0}-x_{1}. From Fact 2.15 we know that points in Z𝑍Z are good. Summarizing:

  1. (i)

    |Y|=x0𝑌subscript𝑥0\left|Y\right|=x_{0}, all y∈Y𝑦𝑌y\in Y are bad and satisfy o−​(y)∈Di0superscript𝑜𝑦subscript𝐷subscript𝑖0o^{-}(y)\in D_{i_{0}}.

  2. (ii)

    |Z|=x0−x1𝑍subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1\left|Z\right|=x_{0}-x_{1}, all z∈Z𝑧𝑍z\in Z are good and satisfy o−​(z)∈Di0superscript𝑜𝑧subscript𝐷subscript𝑖0o^{-}(z)\in D_{i_{0}}.

This implies that Y𝑌Y and Z𝑍Z are disjoint and

x0+x0−x1=|Y|+|Z|=|Y∪Z|=|o−​(Y∪Z)|⩽|Di0|⩽w,subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1𝑌𝑍𝑌𝑍superscript𝑜𝑌𝑍subscript𝐷subscript𝑖0𝑤x_{0}+x_{0}-x_{1}=\left|Y\right|+\left|Z\right|=\left|Y\cup Z\right|=\left|o^{-}(Y\cup Z)\right|\leqslant\left|D_{i_{0}}\right|\leqslant w,

where the last inequality holds as Di0subscript𝐷subscript𝑖0D_{i_{0}} is an antichain in 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P} (Fact 2.7(iii)). ∎

Proof of Lemma 2.14..

∎

Lemmas 2.13 and 2.14 provide us with a system of inequalities involving all the xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}’s:

x0+x1+…+xj+xj−xj+1⩽w,j=0,…,k.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗1𝑤𝑗0…𝑘x_{0}+x_{1}+\ldots+x_{j}+x_{j}-x_{j+1}\leqslant w,\ j=0,\ldots,k.

Note that these are the inequalities used for the lower bound. Here, for the completion of the proof of Proposition 2.6 we need a final lemma to bound the number x0+wsubscript𝑥0𝑤x_{0}+w of chains used by Algorithm.

Lemma 2.18.

x0⩽(φ−1)⋅wsubscript𝑥0⋅𝜑1𝑤x_{0}\leqslant(\varphi-1)\cdot w.

Proof.

We weight the j𝑗jth inequality with the Fibonacci number F2​(k−j)+1subscript𝐹2𝑘𝑗1F_{2(k-j)+1} and take the sum of weighted inequalities:

(5)

Using the well-known Fibonacci identity ∑j=0kF2​(k−j)+1=∑j=0kF2​j+1=F2​k+2superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑘subscript𝐹2𝑘𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑘subscript𝐹2𝑗1subscript𝐹2𝑘2\sum_{j=0}^{k}F_{2(k-j)+1}=\sum_{j=0}^{k}F_{2j+1}=F_{2k+2} we can simplify the double-sum:

x0​F2​k+2+x0​F2​k+1⩽w​F2​k+2.subscript𝑥0subscript𝐹2𝑘2subscript𝑥0subscript𝐹2𝑘1𝑤subscript𝐹2𝑘2x_{0}F_{2k+2}+x_{0}F_{2k+1}\leqslant wF_{2k+2}.

x0⩽F2​k+2F2​k+3⋅w⩽(φ−1)⋅w.subscript𝑥0⋅subscript𝐹2𝑘2subscript𝐹2𝑘3𝑤⋅𝜑1𝑤x_{0}\leqslant\frac{F_{2k+2}}{F_{2k+3}}\cdot w\leqslant(\varphi-1)\cdot w.

The last inequality is due to the fact that the sequence (F2​k+2F2​k+3)k⩾0subscriptsubscript𝐹2𝑘2subscript𝐹2𝑘3𝑘0(\frac{F_{2k+2}}{F_{2k+3}})_{k\geqslant 0} is monotonically increasing with the limit φ−1𝜑1\varphi-1. ∎

The statement of Lemma 2.18 was the last piece of the puzzle. The number of chains used by ALG is bounded by

xU+x0⩽w+(φ−1)⋅w.subscript𝑥𝑈subscript𝑥0𝑤⋅𝜑1𝑤x_{U}+x_{0}\leqslant w+(\varphi-1)\cdot w.

This completes the proof of Proposition 2.6 and hence of Theorem 1.1.
